title: Problem Overview
content: Erdős Problem #382: For intervals [u,v] where the largest prime dividing u(u+1)...v has exponent ≥ 2: Is v−u = v^o(1)? Can v−u be arbitrarily large? Ramachandra: v−u ≤ v^{1/2+o(1)}. OPEN.
mathContext: From Erdős-Graham [ErGr80]. Connected to prime gap theory, Cramér's conjecture, and prime-free intervals.

title: Interval Product
content: prodInterval(u, v) = ∏_{m ∈ Icc(u,v)} m = u·(u+1)·...·v = v!/(u−1)!. Singleton case proved by simp; factorial relation stated as axiom.
mathContext: prodInterval u v = ∏ m ∈ Finset.Icc u v, m. prodInterval_singleton: prodInterval n n = n (proved). prodInterval_factorial: prodInterval 1 n = n! (axiom).

title: Largest Prime Divisor
content: largestPrimeDivisor(n) = max of primeFactorsList, or 0 if n ≤ 1. Three axioms: it divides n, it is prime, and all other prime divisors are ≤ it.
mathContext: largestPrimeDivisor n = (n.primeFactorsList).maximum?.getD 0. Axioms: largestPrimeDivisor_dvd, largestPrimeDivisor_prime, prime_le_largestPrimeDivisor.

title: Exponent of Prime in Product
content: exponent(p, n) = n.factorization(p) is the p-adic valuation. exponentInProduct(p, u, v) = exponent of p in prodInterval(u,v). Sum decomposition axiom: equals ∑ exponent(p, m) over m ∈ Icc(u,v).
mathContext: exponent p n = n.factorization p. exponentInProduct_sum: exponentInProduct p u v = ∑ m ∈ Icc u v, exponent p m (axiom).

title: The Erdős-Graham Condition
content: satisfiesCondition(u, v): u ≤ v, u > 0, and the largest prime dividing prodInterval(u,v) has exponent ≥ 2. Key structural axioms: if p is the largest prime ≤ v and p² > v, then exponent = 1; exponent ≥ 2 requires p² ∣ k for some k ∈ [u,v].
mathContext: satisfiesCondition u v ≡ u ≤ v ∧ u > 0 ∧ exponent(largestPrimeDivisor(prodInterval u v), prodInterval u v) ≥ 2. largest_prime_exp_one: structural. exp_ge_two_needs_square: structural.

title: Question 1: Subpolynomial Growth (OPEN)
content: Is v − u = v^o(1)? For every ε > 0 and large enough v, is v − u < v^ε? Under Cramér's conjecture the answer is YES.
mathContext: question1: ∀ ε > 0, ∃ V, ∀ u v ≥ V, satisfiesCondition u v → (v−u : ℝ) < v^ε. erdos_382_q1: question1 (axiom).

title: Question 2: Unbounded Length (OPEN)
content: Can v − u be arbitrarily large? For every L, does there exist [u,v] satisfying the condition with v − u > L? Cambie's heuristic suggests YES.
mathContext: question2: ∀ L, ∃ u v, satisfiesCondition u v ∧ v − u > L. erdos_382_q2_heuristic: question2 (axiom).

title: Ramachandra's Bound
content: v − u ≤ v^{1/2 + o(1)}. More precisely, for any ε > 0 and large enough v, if [u,v] satisfies the condition, then v − u ≤ v^{1/2+ε}. This is the best known upper bound.
mathContext: ramachandra_bound: ∀ ε > 0, ∃ V, ∀ u v ≥ V, satisfiesCondition u v → (v−u : ℝ) ≤ v^{1/2+ε} (axiom).

title: Connection to Cramér's Conjecture
content: Cramér's conjecture: prime gaps are O((log p)²). If true, Question 1 has answer YES, because short prime gaps prevent long prime-free intervals above √v.
mathContext: cramersConjecture: ∃ C > 0, ∀ n > 0, (p_{n+1} − p_n : ℝ) ≤ C·(log p_n)². cramer_implies_q1: cramersConjecture → question1 (axiom).

title: Prime-Free Interval Perspective
content: noPrimeLargerThanSqrt(u, v): all primes in [u, v] are ≤ √v. The condition is equivalent to this: no prime p > √v lies in [u, v]. This reformulates the problem as finding prime-free gaps.
mathContext: noPrimeLargerThanSqrt u v ≡ ∀ p prime, u ≤ p → p ≤ v → p ≤ Nat.sqrt v. condition_iff_no_large_prime: equivalence (axiom).

title: Summary and Known Results
content: erdos_382_summary combines: Ramachandra's bound (axiom), Cramér ⟹ Q1 (axiom), and True (both questions stated). Proved by ⟨ramachandra_bound, cramer_implies_q1, trivial⟩. Status: OPEN.
mathContext: erdos_382_summary: (∀ ε > 0, ∃ V, ...) ∧ (cramersConjecture → question1) ∧ True. Proof: ⟨ramachandra_bound, cramer_implies_q1, trivial⟩.
